comment: -di has a limited translative meaning, but elative seems to be a more consistent and common way of expressing translative

comment: to denote translative abl2 is used, but abl1 and abl2 can also mean translative in combination with ALOC suffix. There is also a translative =bito enclitic clearly stated in the grammar, though I will treat it just as an adposition and thus abl2 and abl1-ALOC get priority.
translation_as_in_source: ‘Do you hear any sound through the earth?’ (N)
translation: Do you hear any sound through the earth?

comment: magomedbekova1971 c.70: "Направительный и сквозной падежи в собственно-каратинском диалекте по значению часто не дифференцированы, в токитинском очи противопоставляются более отчетливо." Even in grammars translative = elative and authors make no effort to distinguish the two.
